identified-content.person: DE GUARDIOLA, JEANNE LOURDES (JEANNE LOURDES CALLANAN)

block.p: Jeanne Lourdes de Guardiola, a daughter of Wanda Davenport of Ridgewood, N.J., and Roberto de Guardiola of New York, was married last evening to William Francis Callanan, a son of Grace Callanan of Southampton, N.Y., and John H. Callanan of Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. John W. Cook, an Episcopal priest and the president of the Henry Luce Foundation, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's father and stepmother, Joanne de Guardiola, in Southampton.

The bride, 29, graduated cum laude from Bryn Mawr College and was a Luce scholar in 1993 and 1994 in Bangkok. Until April, she was an assistant vice president for Indian and Southeast Asian art at Sotheby's in New York.

Jeanne Lourdes de Guardiola, a daughter of Wanda Davenport of Ridgewood, N.J., and Roberto de Guardiola of New York, was married last evening to William Francis Callanan, a son of Grace Callanan of Southampton, N.Y., and John H. Callanan of Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. John W. Cook, an Episcopal priest and the president of the Henry Luce Foundation, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's father and stepmother, Joanne de Guardiola, in Southampton.

The bride, 29, graduated cum laude from Bryn Mawr College and was a Luce scholar in 1993 and 1994 in Bangkok. Until April, she was an assistant vice president for Indian and Southeast Asian art at Sotheby's in New York.

Her father is the president of De Guardiola Advisors, an investment banking concern in New York. He is also a director of Amvescap, a London mutual fund company. Her mother is a manager of operations at Transamerica Flood Hazard Certification in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J. The bride's stepmother is an interior designer in New York, and her stepfather, Martin Cohen, is a software developer in Wayne, N.J., for BAE Systems, a British aerospace company.

The bridegroom, 29, graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and is a stock and commodities analyst at Soros Fund Management in New York. He is also the founder of the Ganesha Foundation, which provides computers and technology for children at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital in New York.
His father, who is retired, was an executive vice president at Computer Associates International, the software company in Islandia, N.Y.
